text: Saturday the 15th of April 1989 the FA
Cup semi-final between Liverpool and
Nottingham Forest is due to kick off at
3:00 p.m. the match is being held at
Sheffield Wednesday's Hillsborough
ground all 54,000 tickets in Seoul
by noon on the day of the cup tie a few
fans have started to arrive Liverpool
supporters have been allocated the West
End of the Hillsborough Stadium so their
route will keep them away from
Nottingham Forest fans arriving from the
south this also means the Liverpool
supporters will all have to pass through
one entrance Leppings Lane 10,000
Liverpool supporters have tickets for
the standing terraces they will have to
enter through just seven turnstiles by
2:00 p.m. a little over two thousand
have done so meaning eight thousand are
still to come in the hour before kickoff
after passing through the turnstiles
many fans go straight down the tunnel
leading into the central pens behind the
goal pence three and four buy a quarter
past two a crowd is starting to build
outside the stadium
it increases rapidly over the next 15
minutes
flow through the turnstiles is steady
slow inside a loudspeaker message asks
people on the terrace to move forwards
and spread along sideways but high
fences divide the Pens and gates between
them out the back so the more full the
Pens become the harder it is to switch
in the police control box the man in
charge of the match Chief Superintendent
David duckenfield and another officer
discuss whether to delay the kickoff to
give people more time to get into the
ground they decide against outside
supporters are pressing into the
turnstiles and along side a large exit
gate called gate see by a quarter to
three five and a half thousand people
retract through the turnstiles meaning
there are still more than four thousand
fans with tickets for the terraces
outside the ground
thousands are now packed into the
Leppings Lane bottleneck stationed
outside Superintendent Roger Marshall
makes several requests for the mission
to open the exit gates to relieve the
pressure inside the ground for central
pens are filling up Chief Superintendent
duckenfield gives the order and gates
see is opened more than 2,000 fans enter
many head into the packed pens three and
four the gate remains open for about
five minutes during that time the
players come onto the pitch and the
crowd surges forwards the match kicks
off just before 3:00
the crush at the front of pens 3 & 4 is
now highly dangerous a barrier breaks in
pen 3 and people fall forwards it also
increases the pressure on those at the
front as the crush intensifies some fans
escape by climbing over the fence at the
front of the pens it becomes apparent
that a disaster is unfolding and please
stop the match at six minutes past three
desperate people are lifted over the top
of the fences and fans in the upper
stand pull others to safety place try to
free those at the front through the
narrow gates near the pitch there are
not enough stretches and supporters use
advertising hoardings to carry the
injured the first ambulance arrives on
the pitch at 14 minutes past 3 but many
fans already fatally injured
you
